commentBody:
Pretty pictures.

Pretty easy.

And it is a rebus puzzle, isn't it?








no emus with an instrument?

HORNBILL took me a little longer because it's not exactly like the other ones, right? It's not a BILL playing a HORN. Or am I missing something? (I frequently do). Still, I liked the puzzle a lot; I like the variety of doing something slightly different, even if it was easier than I was expecting for a Thursday. And the drawings were fun.

I don‚Äôt normally complain about puzzles  ‚Ä¶.. but.  This one was very cute, but way too easy for a Thursday.  I‚Äôm ok with easier puzzles early in the week, but Thursday through Sunday I hope for at least a bit of a challenge, and relish the real toughies.

I don't mind the new app layout, but it would be *really* nice if the Games app allowed you to access the Wordplay column for any given puzzle directly from said puzzle itself. Having to hop over to the Times app and click through several nested sections is tedious.

(Cute puzzle today, but yeah, really easy. Only missed a personal-best time because I solved on my phone.)
Easy for a Thursday. I could do without the cutesy clues.

Count me in in the way too easy for a Thursday crowd. Cute idea but there must be someway to clue it without totally giving it away in obvious pictures. Also agree that HORNBILL doesn‚Äôt exactly fit the theme pattern.
Easy for a Thursday but loved the puzzle and the drawings. Nicely done
Surprised by how easy it was, but liked the illustrations -- fun to have the variety of clues.

Well, I liked it. 

Whenever anyone asks me, like Grumio from Taming of the Shrew, ‚ÄúIs there any man has rebus‚Äôd your worship?‚Äù I like it when I can say, ‚ÄúWhy yes, yes they have. Esha Datta rebus‚Äôd me today and it felt like the Thursday puzzle had sprouted Egyptian hieroglyphs. It doesn‚Äôt happen often and it was loads of fun to solve.‚Äù

Not a PB but almost - which probably means that Fri and Sat this week will be bears.  HORNBILL didn't fit the pattern of the other animals but, once again, it's easy to criticize when I have never constructed a crossword myself.  I knew 43D immediately but SCHWA is one of those words that I can never spell without looking it up; so I had to rely on crosses.
I loved it! Cute theme, cute cartoons, and the double-entendre revealer was a great laugh üòÇ

Vis-a-vis the continual debate over "the puzzles are getting easier" vs. "no, you're getting better", I usually side with the latter.  

But this week's puzzles are testing my resolve with this position.  There has been no meat in any of these puzzles, and this one should have been a Tuesday at best.  

Next you'll see "Canine pet" for DOG.

BTW, AARE has been clued 328 total times, but only three times (including this time) since 2015, with the last one before this in 2018. Today's exact clue has been used 12 times in the Shortz Era and dozens of times prior.  The best clue, from 2013, was "Swiss bank depositor?"

Cape Breton fiddlers occasionally use a ‚Äúwild note‚Äù among their repertoire of ornaments for a tune. You substitute a higher pitch for a regular melody note of the tune.
It jumps out and hits the listener right between the ears. 

Now, we have a drawing to go with that: the wild fiddler crab!

This puzzle startled me.  Instead of the clever misdirects and nuanced clues of a typical Thursday that provide a delightful challenge, this puzzle pedantically telegraphed the answers with visual cartoons.  It reminded me of worksheets in grade school where an image was placed with a blank, and one needed to spell out the word.

Many folks are complaining about the ‚Äúnew‚Äù app layout. Since I took a look at the Info (capital I) link before solving, I knew to upgrade. The start page of the iPhone app looks to me pretty much the same as it did yesterday. I wonder what I‚Äôm missing?

Since I wasn‚Äôt familiar with HORNBILL, I very simply and naively interpreted the illustration as a bird‚Äôs beak (or bill) playing the horn. 

A fun puzzle, clever theme and skillful artwork. 

Nice work, Esha and Daniel.

I would toot my own horn about how quickly I finished the puzzle, but I doubt that it would be heard above the general cacophony from all the other tootles and the general applause for this fun puzzle.  The illustrations were perfect for the clues and the whole solve was delightful. 

Thank you, Esha Datta, we enjoyed a little  ZAATAR to spice up our Thursday.
My fastest Thursday ever!  Very fun.  Laughed at INATUB!
Like if you also had a Thursday PB!

?

[Ahem]

And now the Times are here
With pictured clues, I feel uncertain 
My joy of solving grids
Might take a dive, my stats may worsen.
I've learned so many words
And unraveled rebuses that filled in such a sly way 
And now, with little pics  -
I'll solve the Time's Way.

Yes there were grids, I'm sure you knew,
Words wouldn't fit, and you felt screwed.
But through it all, you had no doubt
Those clues would change, you'd cuss and shout.
So face it all, stay tall and proud, and solve the Time's Way.

For what is a solver?
What has he got?
If not gold stars, well not a lot.
If not clued words that he can read,
Then give him pictures that he can see!
Let the records show, I may be slow, to solve the Time's Way.


üòâ
Another unusually easy one this week, but the Mini took me thrice as long as normal.
I leaped right over this one. So easy for a Thursday!

Cute puzzle, although pretty easy; Deb's calling it a beginner's Thursday puzzle is spot on. It was nice to see pictorial rebuses for once, though.

Nice sophomore effort, Etta, and thanks.

Today I‚Äôm reading comments about how programmers don‚Äôt deserve their pay because of how the new app looks.

Are the moderators asleep?

As for the puzzle‚Ä¶ spent way too long trying to figure out what DOOR DIE meant.

my favorite themed puzzle of the new year thus far, excellence on all counts. i especially loved seeing ZAATAR and LAHIRI and that graceful TRUMPETER SWAN floating across the middle of the grid. 
kudos to you, Esha, on a wonderfully original and playful sophomore effort. if you read this let‚Äôs make a puzzle sometime :)

I am going to find a new puzzle provider.
 why do entities something that is going well.

Bravo to Daniel Savage for the excellent illustrations.
It takes great talent to visually say so much with such few strokes, reminding me of Picasso's "Sleeping Woman."(the drawing, not the painting.)
Impressive artwork, Mr. Savage!

As for the puzzle, I cracked myself up with DOORDIE. Major dook. 
The rest flowed unencumbered and in good time, light and breezy.
The animals are having a party so I figured so would I. 

Thank you, Ms. Datta!
Enjoyed the theme, but wasn‚Äôt a huge fan of the Heche natick with the 2 other surnames :(

Sound design, if a bit drawn out.





cc: emu handler

Well, definitely way too easily clued for a Thursday puzzle. But focusing on the positive, FIDDLER CRAB crossing TIDAL is nice. And then there's the mention of Ms Heche clued to one of my favorite movies, Wag the Dog. Here's a somewhat NSFW scene that is not for those with delicate sensibilities. (This is nothing.) https://youtu.be/bjerGldHsD8?si=mnO-1jB7Kk_PObxc

FIDDLER CRAB did not immediately spring to mind, but I quickly got the idea with HARP SEAL.

I couldn‚Äôt tell what sort of bird the HORNBILL was supposed to be (though now that I know, it‚Äôs a fine drawing of that species, especially given how small and simple it had to be). As an answer, HORNBILL doesn‚Äôt fit the theme as well as the other ones. 

Cute but not particularly challenging.
PB Thursday for me - cute but easy illustrations.

The personal bests have been few and far between, so a little surprising to bag another one.  Got fiddler crab right off the bat and trumpeter swan right after that.  Certainly paved the way for a quicker finish.

To have two double-a words in Zataar and Aare is a nice little touch, and it made me notice how many entries had two a's in them: samosas, avia, Albany, aerate, catan, abdicate, harp seal and of course the One We Could Do Without: Gaza. Just too loaded a word to use around The Shire.

Of course, the anagram for Trumpeter Swan is a phrase that google turned up ZERO results for: SAW TRUMP REPENT. No one can imagine using that phrase in a sentence, I guess, even in a work of fiction. After the Stormy Daniels trial, what will his total HORN BILL be?

Just want to give a shoutout to HORNBILL, which was new to many folks in the comments. This one made me smile because I watch a livestream of a birdcam in South Africa and hornbills often come to the feeder. Out of all the animal names, for me that was the one that was recognizable as a type of animal and not just a literal interpretation of the picture. 

As a musician I loved the illustrations. 

INATUB was a fun gimme as well.

Thanks, Esha, for a delightful puzzle! I knew these animals because of my kids who, like yours, had vivid imaginations in their youth.  

I was surprised to get so many clues, and solved with another personal best. I hope there are few grousers regarding the pictures. They were so fun!

Great sophomore (but not sophomoric) effort!

Loved the picture rebuses (rebi?)! Beautiful illustrations, and I could actually understand them. Some very clever clues and answers - 1D, 46A (looking at you, door die, lol), and 56a especially. Some tough ones too, for me at least, like 51D and 62A. Not unfair by any means, just names I did not know. 
Thank you Esha, for a lovely Thursday puzzle!

I don‚Äôt like the look of the new UI, but I won‚Äôt argue over aesthetics, to each their own. 

However, I will argue over functionality. I don‚Äôt like the clock showing while working on the puzzle; I find it distracting, so I have that feature turned off in settings. I do like to see my time when I‚Äôm done, which previously I could easily do by simply closing the puzzle and getting back to the games Home Screen, which showed me the time for each recently completed puzzle. Now that time is gone, requiring an additional step to find my time (going to the stats tab). I could understand If the time was removed to save space or to present other info, but no, there is now more space being filled with empty background and less information. Way too much empty background for a small phone screen.  Aesthetics aside, this seems like a poor design choice. There‚Äôs plenty of empty space in the new design, please put the times for recently completed puzzles back on the Home Screen.
Esha, what a fabulous and refreshing puzzle!!

I was surprised when the crossings made it clear ONESIE was the answer for 48D. Speaking as someone who has changed thousands (!) of diapers and done up countless snaps on onesies, these are typically worn by infants, not toddlers. How would you even potty train a toddler who‚Äôs wearing a onesie?

Nice job, Esha Datta. DO OR DIE seems to have won stump-of-the-day! It was my last entry. Must be something visually that got us all??? Light and melodious for a Thursday, Nice treat.
(Hi, Deb Amlen :) always a joy on a Wednesday night to read.)
This was fun'n'fast, my fatsest in fact. Must say I much prefer the doodles to a rebus on a Thursday! Thanks for ANEW approach to clueing.
NAILED IT. In one third my normal time for Thursday I ARRIVEd at the solution, and without looking up a single fact which I always have to do on Thursdays. NO IDEA how I did that.I feel invincible!

I love picture puzzles and thought this one was a lot of fun. Was it the hardest Thursday puzzle I‚Äôve encountered? No. But did I enjoy doing it? Absolutely. Not every puzzle will appeal to every subscriber, but I call fowl on anyone who can‚Äôt appreciate a cute musical bird.
Maybe not the best idea to have the solution to the image clues in the image description, that's not really how accessibility works...Disappointing

Could somebody please explain the theme to me? I read the column but I still don't get it, possibly because I know nothing about baseball. Still, I would like to know what the theme was about. Obviously I understand the link between the pictures and what they solve to, but the baseball connection is lost on me. And please, kindly make the explanation as easy as you can, assuming I know nothing about any of the things involved (because that is probably true).

Btw, a picture puzzle is what a rebus means in Polish, and I actually enjoyed it more than the typical NYT puzzle üòÉ.

Also, I must say I personally did not enjoy the three proper names crossing at the bottom of the puzzle, and the SE corner was just too hard for me - I had to look up stuff, and only understood how MELROSE made sense after the lookup (my mother watched that show all those years ago, and sometimes I joined her).

The best part of this puzzle was the revealer! I wasn‚Äôt expecting it and actually did laugh out loud, so thank you for that!

If I do say so myself I rarely Natick, but for HECHE/LAHIRI I ran the alphabet. TIL so much and thanks for the education.

I did love seeing yummy ZAATAR. I didn‚Äôt like seeing GAZA. If you‚Äôre anything like me you do these puzzles to escape to a wordplay paradise for just a moment before getting back to the big issues.

Loved seeing the picture clues, something a little different for a Thursday theme, and don‚Äôt mind it being a bit easy for a Thursday.  

Something has happened to my getting to the puzzle and Worlde .  Also when I tried to recommend a comment I got a strange page saying I needed to put in my password.  I can‚Äôt remember how I eventually got back to the comments.

The pictures were so literal, the clues were not really clues but answers.  If this ran on a Tuesday, it would have been cute, but on a Thursday?  Kind of disappointing.  Esha did a great job, the editors, not so much.

Total agreement with others who pointed out the tone deafness of the GAZA clue.  That never should have made it to print.

I did love seeing ZAATAR.  Years ago, when I purchased ZAATAR for the first time, it was disappointing.  The dish I made with it was underwhelming.  What I didn't know back then is that there is ZAATAR and ZAATAR spice blend, ZAATAR being just one ingredient in the spice blend.  After mixing it with sumac, etc. it was perfect.  One of my favorite blends now.
I had the hardest time figuring out the last picture clue. The beak is more like a parrot than a HORNBILL, so it threw me for a loop. I did wonder what that thing was on top of the parrot's head...

Loved it. 

Learned I know very few specific animal names, but the crosses
got me there!

With a ‚Äúcrushed‚Äù ankle, the trek from my bed to the 
kitchen couch is a long, somewhat terrifying journey.
I search for any real motivation to awkwardly get out from under my covers.

Today it was,
‚ÄúWhat silliness may be waiting for me in the Thursday puzzle?‚Äù

Then, opening to sweet doodles, I knew I was right
to expect a little gift.

Thank you Esha.
I needed that.

Congratulations  Esha Datta on your sophomore entry, and loved the "YOUREONMUTE" debut from December.  If I read your comments correctly the pictures were not your creation  but added by the editors.  

I would love to know what the original clues were.  Scanned the comments but did not see any speculation.  

Cluing could have been turned up a notch or two but I'm glad I decided to complete today's puzzle.
The notion that all those animals are capable of playing those instruments is patently absurd. A bird playing a horn, without lips? Not likely! The pictures are cute, though, so I'm letting it pass.

Two things I loved about this puzzle.

One, it had pop.  Turns out that 16 of the answers have been used less than 10 times in the 80 years of NYT puzzles, and five of those answers are NYT answer debuts.  One of those debuts, ZA‚ÄôATAR, I may have unknowingly tasted in Middle Eastern restaurants, but after rabbit-holing it online ‚Äì a journey filled with lauds about its flavor -- I‚Äôd now like to knowingly give it a try.

Two, the revealer.  While I was solving this, pretty much dashing through it, at one point I thought that man, this is a lightweight Thursday; what it needs to make it satisfying is a great revealer.  And Esha came through!  Fabulous wordplay, reparsing the baseball term ‚Äúwild pitch‚Äù in a most wacky and wonderful way.

After seeing the text clues to the theme answers (see my reply to @john just a little earlier), well, I would have preferred having them as the theme clues, delightful and charming as the drawings were.  The text clues were end-of-the-week tough and, IMO, would have been more Thursday-appropriate.

But the puzzle‚Äôs pop and revealer shined so brightly that I still left the grid thinking, ‚ÄúExcellent one!‚Äù  Great theme and great spark in this one, Esha ‚Äì thank you so much for making it!

I agree with all who thought it was easy for a Thursday, but it was still an enjoyable puzzle.

I was amused by the little illustrations and the punny revealer. 

The only downside was my discomfort over a single clue, and the divided comments I knew would be the result. I do crosswords to give my mind a respite from the depressing realities of the world, I certainly don't want to see them dredged up in the comments.
I thought DOORDIE was a new word for me, so I looked it up.  Chuckled when even Google knew it was DO OR DIE.
I'm not sure how everyone else found this to be easy--pretty challenging for me. Felt like a Thursday for sure. Am I the only one?

Call me a curmudgeon, but I was underwhelmed:

Once I entered "FIDDLER CRAB," I thought: "is that's all there is? The whole reason a fiddler crab is call a fiddler crab anyway, is because he looks like he's holding a violin." 

The drawing of the trumpeter swan bore much resemblance to Louis from E. B. White's *the Trumpet of the Swan*, the last--and least--of his novels for children; or more precisely, illustrator Edward Frascino's drawing of Louis.

HORNBIrd kept me on Medrose Place wayy too long. Henceforth, I will always write "deicer" with a hyphen ("de-icer") or, better yet, a dieresis ("de√Øcer"), just as an affectation.

Finally, y'all are spared any links from me today, as it appears that no√∂ne has ever composed a Quartet for Horn, Trumpet, Harp, and Violin, much less a Quintet for English Horn, Horn, Trumpet, Harp, and Violin; or at least recorded it and posted it on Youtube. I have the afternoon off--I shall spend it composing one, using Cagean aleatoric processes.

A muse not related to today‚Äôs puzzle‚Ä¶

David Steinberg, I miss you!  Yes, In December you retired from making puzzles, but I miss you already.  Your puzzles had such wit, class, and craft.  They were exemplars of the art of constructing.  Consistently so, through your huge output of 111 in the Times.  

I hunger for your puzzles.  Sometimes a tv series ends, and ends at just the right time, and I‚Äôm glad it didn‚Äôt run longer.  But I don‚Äôt feel that way about your puzzles.  I want them to continue.

I want to respect your life and needs, so how about a compromise, say, one or two puzzles a year, somehow squeezed into your busy life.  Those theme ideas still come to your fertile brain, don‚Äôt they?  And I‚Äôm guessing you write those ideas down.  Just one or two puzzles a year.  Yes?

Think about it.  Please?  Pretty please?

I found this puzzle much easier than usual Thursday mostly because the mechanism if the ‚Äútrick‚Äù was evident. half the joy of a Thursday is discovering what the trick is. 

On a more controversial note: did anyone else find it ironic that a diversity sponsored puzzler used the three men in a tub clue? This is the second time in a week we have had this clue and I find it jarring every time since this version of the rhyme potentially underscores the outing and social condemnation of personal choices among consenting adults. ‚ÄòRub-a-dub-dub, three men in a tub. And who do you think they be? The butcher, the baker the candlestick maker. Turn them out, knaves all three.‚Äô

The original isn‚Äôt men in a tub at all. It‚Äôs maids in a tub in a 14th century fair‚Äôs peep show: ‚Äò‚Ä¶ho rub-a-dub, three maids in a tub. And who do you think were there? The butcher, the baker, the candlestick maker, and all of them going to the fair.'

Way too easy for a Thursday, I was hoping for something more fun. 

My opinion on the 10A clue is that it‚Äôs technically accurate. Conflict is a very broad term that can be applied to wars or family arguments. In crossword puzzles, I‚Äôm not looking for current-day news analysis, nor a particular point of view (although I have mine).

Also, for years, journalists have referred to the ongoing cycle of violence in the region as the Mideast conflict, so I don‚Äôt fault the editors for thinking of this clue as an anodyne description. But perhaps any reference to Gaza should have been delayed until quieter times.

I loved this puzzle!  KUDOS to the constructor.  However, BOO on the editors for missing a once-in-four-years opportunity for having a leap year day themed puzzle.  I love when a puzzle's theme matches the holiday or special day on which it appears.

Of course, the instant the printer spit out the puzzle, I had the trick, the entries, and most of the fun...  NAILED IT.
But enjoyed the puzzle, being a birder, so Thanks! To Esha Datta!

The Ford F-150 is the BIG 'big name in trucks.'  We had one long-bed F-150 *without a crew-cab* that we bought used after an internet search.  It was up in Missouri, but they said they'd drive it down to us in Arkansas.  All they needed to know was what name to put on the title.  DHubby gave both our names....and the guy had a  fit!  "You don't want your wife's name on that title!  You could go out of town and she would sell it out from under you!"  DHubs really had to get insistent about it.  We made sure the cashier's check was made out from just me....  (Ever after, we've wondered about the state of affairs in Missouri marriages...)  

Not a week went by tht we didn't find a note on the windshield: "If you would like to sell this truck, please call..."  But once we finished our remodeling, we turned it in as the first "Cash for Clunkers" transaction at the Ford dealer...Fortunately we had been lazy and left three years'-worth of registration slips in the glove compartment to prove the required length of ownership.  That was when I got the Escape Hybrid...whch DHubby insisted was "too old" after 12 years of faithful service.  I donated it to Habitat.  The End.

Just one word for all of you complaining about the changes to the app:
    UNINSTALL
I solve  on an Android without it and everything is fine (except only 3 comments unless you press see more). And maybe some honest person in IT knows that the version is bad, because I'm getting fewer recommendations to install it. The IT person just couldn't bring themself to code "Things are better with the app", maybe? Coincidence? [Use of they/them neutral pronoun is deliberate. Like "you" evolving from plural to either, "they" can do the same, I hope.]
   Now MY complaint is the revision to the NYT Table of  Contents (= sign in upper left). Games used to get you to a screen with all of the games and when you'd done one, the back button got you back to the All screen. Now back button gets you  back to where you were when you pressed the = sign. There are routes to the All screen but no longer straightforward ones.
I thought the puzzle was fun, but a Wednesday-level outing, since the cute drawings didn't pose any Thursday-level challenges. [But I didn't appreciate the natick at 12D/26A.]
Generally easy for Thursday, but 51D/62A was a serious Natick for me requiring a Google look up for spellings (which doesn't count as cheating, right?  RIGHT?)

App new? Gesundheit!

I solved this on my computer and found delight in the rebus pictures.

Just to check, I opened the puzzle on my phone, and the pictures showed up fine. I use a Google phone (Android, baby!) and hadn't noticed the app had changed. 

So I liked it. Had to dig up CATAN from the dusty attic of my memory, and took a flyer on the crossing H in LAHIRI and HECHE, and was pleasantly surprised that I was right.

And the pictures again, IMNSHO, were a delightful change-up (which can lead to WILDPITCHES in baseball, by the way....)
I'm relatively new to the world of crosswords (a 2024 hobby) and this was so fun! I love these theme puzzles and this was a challenge but not impossible.

For the first time, I've got a 31 day streak. Technically it's my first calendar month streak, too, even though it's February. Leap year credit! 

Just wanted to share!
@NYT I appreciate the new and improved app. It is better than before. Now, can NYT All Access and Games subscribers please have access to the PDF‚Äôs of the variety puzzles again? Pretty please?
Cute but way too easy for Thursday.

Loved the drawings! Fun puzzle!

But like others here I'm shocked, shocked, that there's no TRIANGLE BUTTERFLYFISH!

A band without a triangle is like a pizza without pineapple!

"Not a hard solve" is so relative, for you maybe. I guess if you've been doing these for years maybe but still plenty of difficulty here for the majority of solvers. I do agree easier for Thursday but by no means not a hard solve for me. 

Theme was fun. Hornbill did not come to me - was able to suss out the rest. Lahiri, heche, aare - I'll just never get these proper nouns. But must be nice for the authors when they google these random strings of letters and find that they work. Heche and Lahiri cross btw, can we try to get away from crossing proper nouns? But obviously "not a hard solve" - who doesn't know these . . . I surely don't.

Got this one without help, loved the picture clues, and as a frequently complainer about tricksy thursday, this one was fun. 

Not the first Thursday I've solved without any assistance, but very satisfying nonetheless.

Everyone is really up in arms about the wrong thing here. Why are we not talking about how heinous that HECHE/LAHIRI/AGEE proper noun crossing was?!













emus: please resolve the conflict in the comments

A bit slow getting HORNBILL as I wanted something like Horned Lark. I think that would have worked with the other theme answers better, but then I don‚Äôt care about theme placement symmetry. Revealer meant very little to me. Also DEPOnE for DEPOSE, which I‚Äôve never been able to tell the difference between. Will go look it up.
Fun fact: HORNBILLs and toucans are an example of convergent evolution. They are not very closely related.
I haven't even solved it yet, the pictures are just SO CUTE that I'm losing my mind, the little crab??? Oh my god. I love them all so much

Pinnipeds get my seal of approval!

(I call them on my flipper phone.)
That was fun!
What is everyone‚Äôs gripe with the app? I just updated and don‚Äôt see any change.
This was fun and stimulating. The drawings are great.
Vonnegut would've liked this one.

Loved this puzzle.
These clues are actually rebuses although not what we usually think of when we hear rebus!
Answers were very easy AND fun!
Loved the revealer too!

Thank you, Esha.  I really had a swell time with an easier than usual Thursday!
very fun puzzle :) thanks for the share

I can make out all the critters, but where are the bleepin' instruments?

I needed the exquisite touch of Leonardo and you gave me Picasso.  Late Picasso, not early Picasso.

Actually, late Picasso in need of a refresher art class.

Look, I'm a word person, not a picture person, and I need all the help I can get.  And the drawings here were...not helpful.

Good cluing though.  "Place for soap" is great and it's the best clue for ETC (33D) I've ever seen.

The less said about the cross of ZAATAR and CATAN, the better.  I thought it might be an "A", but I left it blank so I wouldn't forget to point out how awful it was in my comment.

Bottom line:  Better drawings would have made for a much better puzzle.

This was delightful!  (The seal in the 24-ACROSS clue had a real James Thurber-esque vibe). I, for one, would love to see more crosswords with visual clues.  Congratulations, Esha, on your second Times puzzle.

51D crossing 53A and 62A - if you didn't know two "Pulitzer winning authors" names or the actress, you're essentially screwed. This wasn't like an "ELLA" or "MILA" where you could just figure it out if you had the rest of the clues solved like I did.

Fun Thursday puzzle overall that was otherwise very doable. Just not a big fan of having multiple individuals' last names crossing each other like that especially if they aren't household names. Thank you for the fun!
I know my animals and today knew my authors so no problems but it took me a moment to understand what a DOOR DIE is!

No shirt
No shoes
NO DICE!

Yesterday's head scratcher was CAVA, today it was ZA'ATAR. That can't be right, can it? Learn something new every day.

200+ comments and nobody has complained about TIDAL waves being tsunamis.
Enjoyed the change of pace with the fun drawings. Got a special charge out of COR ANGLAIS as another instrument in the mix. Well done, Esha!
When I opened my print edition newspaper to the puzzle I knew I was going to have fun with this one. Nice job, Esha. We have quite a few 24A in the Sandy Hook National Park right now.

As I write this, I see there are 224 comments. I suspect over half address how (relatively) easy today's puzzle was. So what? It was FUN, and that's why I do crosswords. Sure, I appreciate finishing a more challenging puzzle, too, but today's puzzle gave me joy. Perhaps that was due to the whimsical pictures for some of the clues, and that's fine, too.

Oh, and also a no-lookup, personal best for a Thursday. THAT'S fun! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

The pictures were cute, but a Thursday challenge this was not. 
Perhaps the editors would consider publishing multiple puzzles a day, rated based on their relative degree of difficulty.  Solvers could choose which level they're ready to tackle, whether gentle, moderate or brain buster. . .

another neat, fun puzzle that gets ruined by way too many proper nouns.
AGEE/HECHE/LAHIRI crossing each other really put a black mark on this.
Hmmm NYT is deleting comments about the terrible new GUI.  Can‚Äôt take criticism?  Maybe the should find a new job.   Or do it better.

Great puzzle (cute illustrations)! ‚Ä¶but, wrong day of the week. From FIDDLER CRAB on, I thought (hoped) there‚Äôd be another level of deciphering. 

Its Thursday placement is really a disservice to the constructor.

Sorry for being curmudgeonly‚Ä¶

Just right for a Thursday, in my opinion. LAHIRI is one of my favorite authors, ZA'ATAR is one of my favorites to add to hummus, and The Trumpet of the Swan was my favorite book as a kid- felt like a custom-made puzzle! 

I didn't get DEICER or ARRIVE, but I loved the picture clues and there were lots of interesting words throughout the puzzle.
I have the font set on my Ipad to large. Now the update for the games app caused the icons to be too large to see them properly. Its jarring to open the app now. The update is not an improvement.

So, yes, it was easier than the average Thursday. So what? It was clever, witty and the picture clues were a fun addition. 

I was confused by being served SAMOSA with chutney, until I remembered Mango. The word chutney for me always conjures up a ploughman‚Äôs platter with cheese, ham, pork pie and the obligatory pickled onion, plus lashings of dark, sweet vegetable chutney. But not Piccallili; no foodstuff should ever be luminous yellow!
Fun puzzle, and the drawings were charming!

Yes, I know, it was easier than most Thursday puzzles are. But that didn‚Äôt bother me at all, because it was so whimsical and fun to solve. The pictured animals were easy to identify but that didn‚Äôt take away from the entertainment. Crosses were kind in the places where I needed them, such as MELROSE place, with its veiled capital (the clue, I mean). I‚Äôd never heard of the show, so that was my last spot to fill, once I finally realized the context of ‚Äúsoap‚Äù. There were so many possibilities for the ‚Äúcomics sound‚Äù that crossed it, but I tried BAM, and voila!
I‚Äôm looking forward to your next puzzle, Esha üòä

I had zaatar on an English muffin for breakfast today!
Pop it in the toaster oven to toast the sesame seeds - yum!

For years I'd worked Monday - Wednesday puzzles. The few times I got up the gumption to try a Thursday ended in frustration with clues that bore no relation that I could see to actual words.

Perhaps today's puzzle was unusually easy. Regardless, I not only solved the puzzle unaided--I actually enjoyed it. Thanks!
I don't know if this is the place to discuss the mini, but the Gobi Desert is not the largest desert in Asia, the Arabian desert is.

Sorry I do not like the new UI skin for the app.  The same data now takes up more real estate, making me having to scroll needlessly within the app. 

I don‚Äôt understand if there was even an issue with the previous skin.  Can NYT explain the rationale?

Some alternative clues for 10A:
"Ancient city is famous for its hand-woven carpets, wicker furniture, and pottery"
"Site of fourth-century Saint Porphyrius church"
"Where gauze originated"
"Middle Eastern territory with one of the highest literacy rates in the world"
What is an ATA discount???? In CA we all look for a AAA discount.
This should have been a Wednesday
Cool illustrations! Got confused for a sec and thought I was looking at cartoons from my New Yorker app. I must be getting old ‚Ä¶
In the Mini - Is the largest desert in Asia not the Arabian Desert?

This is one of those puzzles that makes me wish for a week‚Äôs worth of Thursday-style puzzles so that we could vary the difficulty. This was a fun and easy solve, but doesn‚Äôt quite scratch the Thursday itch.

I've been away from the puzzle for a variety of reasons, but I made sure to check in today because I like Thursdays. Today did not fail to delight. I'm both a musician and a baseball fan. I thought today's puzzle was great.

I too have been away for a while, mostly catching a Thursday puzzle here and there from a week or two before, so I haven't been checking the comments - it's too hard to get to Wordplay after a week or two, at least with a browser.

Yeah, Thursdays have definitely been getting easier for many months if not longer. They are still fun, but like some of the others here, I would like to sweat things out more than I have lately.

And I don't think saying so should discourage anyone or make them feel less than. For the past several years I have spent an hour on the Thursday puzzles only to see comments about them taking just 10 or 15 minutes to complete. 

That just reminded me that it is a big world out there and there are some extremely talented people in every sphere. 
It makes sense that some incredibly good solvers are going to do the NYT crosswords.

Hi! Some are saying this was easier than usual but I couldn‚Äôt decide: I actually had trouble with WILD PITCHES, had Asics instead of AVIA, went through the alphabet but didn‚Äôt recognize HRS 
and really needed Deb‚Äôs column to see ARRIVE! So I had fun. Thank you, Esha Detta and congratulations on this beautiful publication!
I loved the animal drawings, too.

Fastest Thursday ever, at under 12.5 min. Very cute theme. Kudos to the artist, because it was immediately evident what the drawings were. No proper names that could not be had by the crosses (except Catan and Zaatar, but I've heard of the former, so was able to find my error). Easy week continues...

The crossing of 51D (a person‚Äôs name) with two other names (53A & 62A) was brutal. Submission guidelines say to avoid having even two names cross, so I‚Äôm surprised that three made it through. Honestly, that area and the adjacent SW corner were a little questionable. 

Other than that, this puzzle was fantastic, easily one of my favorites among recent puzzles. Top tier creative theme, fun and interesting fill, and just the right difficulty to make me really think without feeling completely stuck. My favorite moment was getting my gold star after filling in several complete guesses for letters in the SW corner.

Part 4.  The Taming of Kate

Despite a spirited first encounter II.1.183-274 where her insults are met with suggestive retorts, Kate does not say a word when her father declares "'Tis a match."  with a wedding the coming Sunday.  Why is that?  One school of thought is that every other man she has met has run away cursing her.  Petrucchio is the only one with the wit and confidence to take her on.  Another is that Kate is terrified of being left alone as an unmarried woman and that this may be her only chance to leave her father's house.  I take the wishy-washy position that both are true.

When he has not appeared on the wedding day, she does speak:  (III.2.8) 			
	No shame but mine. I must forsooth be forced
	To give my hand opposed against my heart
	Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen
	Who wooed in haste and means to wed at leisure.

So there is work to be done.  Petrucchio finally arrives.  It is not clear if he is actually late for the ceremony, but he is outrageously dressed and acts disgracefully when it takes place, even striking the priest.  There is a sidebar commentary on perception vs reality to the extent that Clothes make the man.  To make things worse he takes her away to his country house, skipping the wedding feast.

(To be completed in a Reply)

@dizzyspins this is not a rebus puzzle
@GyrndiIm the way "rebus" is used in the context of crosswords is unique‚Äîin every other context, it refers to picture clues as used in this puzzle

@JP Not really. Not any pictorial representation is an original style rebus. A rebus is "a puzzle in which words are represented by combinations of pictures and individual letters; for instance, apex might be represented by a picture of an ape followed by a letter X.", or as an example in a M-W definition, (see the link below for the exact representation): A metal can followed by a C and a U, followed by a well for drawing water, standing for "Can you see well?" https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rebus A rebus contains short elements that represent various parts of a longer word or phrase. Just being a picture doesn't make it a rebus.

@Andrzej A wild pitch is a pitch that goes way off base -- hence a mistake in baseball, since it will actually benefit the batter rather than the pitcher's team. https://www.mlb.com/glossary/standard-stats/wild-pitch As for the connection, my assumption was not exactly the same as the columnist -- it was that animals playing instruments might produce wild pitches, in that their music would be horribly off-key and completely random, as I am assuming that (for example) a crab does not know how to properly play a fiddle, and therefore would end up with something very very wild.

Really curious as to the decision process behind approving the entry and cluing for 10A. I cannot think of another topic guaranteed to generate impassioned and non-crossword-related responses in the Wordplay comments (other than American politics in an election year, maybe), as evidenced by some of the comments here. 

Not expressing an opinion either way -- just making an observation after reading the comments.

As for me, this felt like an overall easier Thursday, but personally thought some of the cluing wasn't that great, but maybe (again) that's just Thursdays for me. For example, I have literally never heard of 61A and don't know a single person who wears that, and I've been an avid runner and triathlete for 10+ years. (I'm sure someone will tell me this entry has been clued 485 times since the launch of the crossword, though)

I really think we need to shy away from stating things are clearly easy. I know this has already been addressed by journalists in the comments, but the fact remains, everyone learns and solves differently. The answers were more readily apparent for frequent Times solvers, but let‚Äôs not eschew potential puzzle players away with what could be misconstrued(or fairly interpreted) as condescension. What if you took away the intense gratification someone felt for solving something they thought was a real challenge, or worse, robbed them of the joy of  attempting to solve future Time‚Äôs Crosswords  because they were too stupid to do something that was deemed easy?

Keep in mind that the most common meaning or usage of a word is not the only way it can be used in a puzzle (15A, 64A, 48D).  In particular, "nothing doing" can mean "I'm not going to agree to that" in the same way that NO DICE does.

57A:  Of course it is.  Your point?

32A:  Here you might have a bit of an argument, but someone will come along to remind you that a clue is a hint, not a definition.  (But the hint should be accurate, I'd think.)  Still I didn't have any problem with it.

@Al  in Pittsburgh   ( 4b as promised)

His behavior at the house is right out of today's brainwashing playbook.  Kate is deprived of food and sleep for several days.  He claims that nothing is good enough for her and berates his servants.  He sends away a Tailor who has made a fine selection of clothes for her.  (We see that he does care for her when he secretly pays the Tailor's bill.)  Some critics have said that this exaggerated carrying-on shows her how badly she used to behave and causes her to reform. I'm skeptical.

Exhausted and hungry she is taken back to town.  Petrucchio presses on, continuing to contradict Kate and Nature itself in the famous back and forth over whether it is the sun or the moon shining upon them or whether old Vincentio is a young woman.  She finally concedes.  (IV.6)

Is the ". . .kiss me, Kate" scene (V.1.132-141) the turning point?  I don't know.  But at a dinner with the three couples and the fathers, large bets are made as to which of the wives will obey their husbands.  This is where Kate wins the pot for Petrucchio and delivers a persuasive speech right out of the Great Chain of Being (V.2.141) including:
	Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper
	Thy head, thy sovereign, one who cares for thee  .  
 I doubt that she believes a word of it but is willing to play the game since her situation seems better than the others.  Persuasion, Perception, and Reality once again. 

The question before the house:  Did they live happily ever after?
Enjoyable puzzle, but fairly easy for a Thursday. This was a good nine minutes below my Thursday average.  I look forward to Thursdays for more of a challenge.

I‚Äôm ok with the new app design except one major complaint. The color codes for the solve progress for each grid are way less intuitive. What I mean is, in the old design you were able to quickly grasp which grids you have solved by the color and fill of the color  (gold, blue, half-filled blue, etc.). Now everything is on the blue background so this is less easy to catch at a glance. I hope I‚Äôm clear and the design team reconsiders the color scheme.

Wow, the new app is terrible. The old one was clean and functional. I could access everything I wanted, the elements were well arranged, and there weren‚Äôt all these awful huge ui elements clogging up the screen. 

Who decides to break something that is working very well in favor of something flashier but less functional? Why was this necessary‚ÄΩ Who is trying to justify their job here? I wish people would follow that old adage about not ‚Äúfixing‚Äù things that aren‚Äôt broken.
